item.description:
I doubt that we'll see James Bond on this hike but 007 would welcome the challenge, intrigue and drama of "THE BONDS." Our adventure will include six (6) 4,000 footers with plenty of flats and spectaculor views. We'll break up the over 20 miles of hiking over two days with camping at the Guyot Campsite (see note below.)

The "Bonds" is the name used to refer to a cluster of three mountains. These peaks are talked about more than they're walked about because they're in the middle of  a 45,000 acre desolation zone known as the Pemigewasset Wilderness.  Because of the length and rigor of this hike I am rating it strenuous. The absence of roads and people make the Pemi attractive for seeing moose, deer, fox and bear. From the summit of these peaks you can see the Franconia Range to the west and the Presidentials to the northeast.

The Pemi is part of the White Mountains National Foreset: http://www.wilderness.net/index.cfm?fuse=NWPS&sec=wildView&WID=450

To ensure a choice campsite for Sat nite we'll need to start early on Sat. Friday night options inlcude hotels around Route 302 and the Sugarloaf campground 1 & 2 on Zealand Road (http://www.recreation.gov/recAreaDetails.do?contractCode=NRSO&facilityId=370445&agencyCode=131.)

Our trek will follow...

Hale Brook Trail to the summit of Mt. Hale (4,054')

Continue on the Lend a Hand Tr to the AMC Zealand Falls Hut for a break

Continue on the Twinway Tr over Mt. Zealand (4,260') &  Mt. Guyot (4,580) to Bondcliff Tr (south)

To Guyot Campsite: Secure site, drop gear, hike 1.4 miles round trip to West Bond (4,540') for possible sunset

Sat nite camp

Sun: Continue south on Bondcliff Trail To Mt. Bond (4,698') and to Bondcliff (4,625')

Continue south on Bondcliff Tr. to Wilderness Tr (west) to Lincoln Woods Tr to

Lincoln Woods Visitors Center on route 112.

 

This hike will require spotting cars at the trailhead and trailend. Weather may cancel  this hike:  http://www.nws.noaa.gov/view/prodsByState.php?state=me&prodtype=public

Mandatory Equipment List:
This list could change based on trail conditions just prior to the hike.

  • Synthetic shirt and waterproof pants. No cotton. No jeans.
  • Wool/ synthetic socks.
  • Sturdy Hiking Boots suitable for uneven terrain.
  • Rain / Wind Jacket with hood. No Ponchos.
  • Warm fleece layer
  • Warm fleece outer layer or wool hat
  • Sleeping Bag
  • Tent or share with someone
  • 3 liters Water (tablets or water filter)
  • Headlamp
  • Spare Lithium batteries for Headlamp. Bring Lithium, not Alkaline batteries.
  • Trail Snacks for two days
  • Lunch for two days and one dinner
  • Map/Compass/Whistle
  • Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's hardly a reason not to have one in your pack)
  • Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)

Other Equipment Suggestions:

  • Sunglasses & sunscreen
  • insect repellant
  • Medications/First Aid Supplies
  • Repair Kit/Knife
  • Trekking Poles
  •  Gaiters
  • Light-weight Emergency Shelter
  • Camera-Binoculars
  • T.P.

No Jeans, Sneakers, or Cotton clothing on the hike!

Note: Guyot Campground: This is a first come first serve site. There's both a small shelter and tent platforms. $8 caretaker fee per person. Upper tent platforms best for sunrise and sunset views. Bottom level platform #5 best for privacy. Water can be sourced from on on-site spring or at the Zealand Hut.

Car Pooling Recommended: Use the comments section to find travel mates.

Guests: If a member wants to bring a guest please contact me via email.

Liability Waiver:
As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.name: The Bond Collection
